title: Are kids becoming more disrespectful nowadays? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, children are ruder and more disrespectful, and have been so for some time. There is a widespread sentiment that such concepts as validating, listening to, giving space, giving freedom of expression and praising the child is uplifting and promotes good, healthy self-esteem. Self-esteem is developed not from ‘free’ praise, but rather from successfully overcoming difficulties appropriate to age. Children who are being praised simply for showing up are being done a huge disservice. This is bullshit. Teaching children good manners, showing them boundaries, teaching them empathy for others, teaching them to leave their phone in their room when they come down to dinner, teaching them to listen to their parents and obey their rules is seen as a form of “abuse” these days, while coddling the children in the form of validating and praising them for everything they do and say is considered good parenting. Nothing could be further from the truth. Self-expression is a lovely piece of psychobabble, but saying “fuck you” to one’s father or calling one’s mother “a bitch” is NOT self-expression - it’s abuse, ill-mannered, self-centered lack of discipline. Children who run freely in restaurants, disrupting diners and putting themselves and waiters at risk are rude, as are their parents for not giving them guidelines. Children who are permitted to kick the seat in front of them are not being well raised. Children who are permitted to curse their parents or their peers are not given good parenting. There must be consequences for disrespect, such as taking away their privileges. Children who throw tantrums just to get their way should be taught that such behavior will not get them what they want. Listen, parents, children will grow up, and whatever you teach them now will express itself later on. A spoiled child will grow up to be a spoiled adult. Not spoiling a child does NOT mean being punitive or abusive - on the contrary. Please teach your children well; teach them right from wrong - kindness and empathy and consideration for others.

It depends on what you mean by “respect.” I’ve heard the old saw “children should respect their elders.” Oddly, it never includes the obvious second half: “Elders should respect their children.” Clearly, most people who say “respect” actually mean “obey without question.” I, like many hundreds of thousands of my fellow rebellious Hippies chose to throw out the “rule book” back in the sixties. There seemed to be no justification for most of these rules, it was simply expected, and usually a swift punishment would follow. This was (and remains) just plain WRONG. Children are not lumps of clay, pets, or possessions. They are not here to serve their parents, they are here to be served BY their parents. Obviously, they require a lot of attention, and many don’t get it. I will repeat myself for the thousandth time and say “Children almost never do what you say, but they almost always do what you do.” If you are disrespectful to them (or anyone else, for that matter,) then that is what they will learn. They will waste no time imitating this disrespectful behavior. If you choose, instead to listen to what they say, and respect their right to speak their truth WHATEVER IT IS, then THAT is what they will learn. They aren’t stupid. They always know when they’re being treated dismissively, and they WILL make you pay. And Pay. And PAY! Our world is full of people walking around who harbor downright prehistoric notions about child-rearing. If I have to hear one more person say “my parents whipped my ass, and I turned out OK,” I will vomit on them. NO, you did NOT “turn out OK! You still think it’s OK to settle your problems by hitting people who are small and helpless.” Despite the FACTS from a lot of studies showing that spanking not only doesn’t work, but it creates severe problems instead, people fall back on this, apparently out of sheer habit. Or maybe a bit of Stockholm Syndrome? What’s worse, many of these so-called adults are not parents now, and plenty of them probably (hopefully) will never be. They still feel qualified to hold forth at great length on how children “should” be raised. The word “should” is always a danger sign - it means that someone is going to try and force me to do something “for my own good.” I don’t do well with “should.” I do even worse with “shouldn’t.” Do parents have the right to set the rules for their children? Of course they do. Do they have the right to enforce them like nasty little martinets? Not so much. So I wonder - are children really “more disrespectful” these days, or are they just waking up a bit?

Why are children more disrespectful today? That's a great question. I think that a lot of it has to do with the current culture in which we live. I wrote in Quora once that I always treated my parents with respect. Period. Sixty years ago, everybody treated their parents that way. Someone who was relatively young, I assume, commented that I was lying, that there was no one who did that. I'm pretty sure that life as I knew it would end if we called our mom anything even semi-nasty. Disrespecting her would be like spitting on your grandma; you simply did not do it. While we might hate having chores to do, accepting discipline, and having high expectations placed on us, we did what we were told. Another factor is how adults treat each other, yelling at retail clerks and having road rage and shooting cops. As they say, values are caught, not taught. With adults showing such little respect for each other, is it any wonder that these attitudes are passed on to our kids? When I taught, the number one rule in my classroom was to treat others with respect. I explained that treating others with respect is a statement of who you are, and not whether or not the other deserves it. I treated my students with great respect and I expected the same in return.

Some might be, but some are really kind. Perhaps I might have observed some of them on a particularly bad or good moment of their day. I also live in a tough blue collar city in New England. Yankee stoicism can be perceived as rude when, really, folks are just minding their own business. Plus, lots of kids have been toId not to talk to strangers; so if I speak to a young person and they don't reply, are they being rude or just doing what their parents told them? I believe there's a general societal perception that civil discourse is falling by the wayside. However, I'm not sure it's not quite that simple. Kids might be less developed as humans, but I wouldn't consider them any less complex than us bigger folks. People are a bit like New England's weather. A few minutes may reveal a completely different attitude and behavior. There are a lot of psychological, political, geographic, economic, environmental and many other variables to consider. But my unscientific opinion of my own observations? Yeah, there seems to be a lot more disrespectful people in the world - at least here in Springfield. Yet, while my opinion MIGHT be somewhat accurate, I'm working on keeping a more neutral mindset and doing what I can to be respectful of others. What they do is up to them.

I have a couple of theories, but they are only theories. We raising kids over 50 years gave us a strange vision into the households of other children over those years. During that time, a lot changed in our country. First, women went back to college and got high powered jobs. A lot of divorces happened also. Before that, my neighborhood women were powerful, educated, but chose to stay at home with their children until they were a bit older. We got together often to share stories, observe the children, and most important, we opened a coop nursery school that was the best school for miles. We were involved with our children, and they were able to see first hand what we did during the day that made our community better. These kids did a lot of things, but they were community minded. They saw first hand how a society functioned and they weren’t afraid to contribute. After the divorces, children had less supervision and parents were glad to let them have what they saw and wanted to keep them quiet and occupied inside. Secondly, nannies appeared on the scene, followed by take out menus, in house food deliveries, electronic devices like cell phones, video games, and entertainment of every kind. I saw children eating junk instead of cooked meals, and the friends of my children stayed inside instead of playing outside using their own imaginations and getting dirty. Children began to want designer clothing, high priced toys, and special food, mostly processed and easy. They became demanding and unhappy, and parents felt guilty and indulged them the way they had indulged themselves. Children stated to see themselves as separate from their parents, with their own culture to the extent that parents felt the need to push them into myriad of activities.People began to hire drivers for their kids to fill in when the parents were at work. The children had their own phones, and some parents actually tolerated a last minute text for any change of plans without expecting their children to talk to them. We saw families existing side by side, with everyone’s phone in their face, and without the need for conversation. Then we saw vacations taken over by the same thing We refused to go along with it, even fighting for our children’s spouses to put away their phones at our table. We heard a lot of “I told you so’s” from our children to their partners. Life really changed, and everyone claims they are too busy. For me they are too busy missing out on their own lives. Children aren’t being inducted into a family, a community, a nation, they are a nation of their own, like little idols. As one of our foreign foster daughters who baby sat neighbor’s kids said it, “Mom, they all like little eggs, you carry in our hand, so they won’t break. Why, Mom.”

“The children now love luxury; they have bad manners, contempt for authority; they show disrespect for elders and love chatter in place of exercise. Children are now tyrants, not the servants of their households. They no longer rise when elders enter the room.”* Sound about right? That quote is roughly 2500 years old, written by Plato and attributed to Socrates. The point being, every generation thinks the next generation is rude and disrespectful. Here’s a tip that should do you wonders: You are not owed respect on account of your age, but your character. If you walk around expecting the youth to treat you as some sort of paragon they will see straight through that. *Attributed to SOCRATES by Plato, according to William L. Patty and Louise S. Johnson, Personality and Adjustment, p. 277 (1953).

Actually today’s kids lack discipline and for that the parents themselves should be disciplined and God fearing. Even before learning ABCD, children should be taught discipline. They should be taught to respect all and do not expect anything in return, be humble and tolerant like a tree. At a tender age they should start this. Prahalada was a great devotee of the Lord. But his father was a demon named Hiranyakasipu who disliked his son being a devotee and devised several means to kill him. He tried to poison him, tried to burn him, threw him from mountain top, put him in a pit of posiouness snakes, had an elephant trample him, tried to drown him in a river – but failed miserably because he was under the full protection of the Lord. Ultimately the Lord appeared as Lord Narasimha and killed the demon father. Non-devotees always try to give trouble to the devotees but fail miserably. A small child, while being cared for by his mother, does not know how the needs of the body for eating, sleeping, lying down, passing water and evacuating are being fulfilled. He is simply satisfied to be on the lap of his mother. Similarly, Prahlada Maharaja was exactly like a small child, being cared for by Govinda. The necessary activities of his body were performed without his knowledge. As a father and mother care for their child, Govinda cared for Prahlada Maharaja, who remained always absorbed in thoughts of Govinda. This is Krishna consciousness.

According to each generation, kids are always ruder than they were as kids. So, based on that logic, yes, all kids are becoming more disrespectful nowadays. More likely though, we just become less patient with the shenanigans of children as we age. We call them rude because they don’t worship us for all of the knowledge we could pass on to them in this exact moment and they really just want to go do something fun. I don’t think kids are more disrespectful of adults. I think adults tend to disrespect the needs of a child to move, play, test boundaries and test tempers.

I wouldn't say more disrespectful, there's been no official concensus on that sort of thing. They'll always act different when they have a bit of agency and room to groe as an individual making mistakes away from home. For anything bigoted, children repeat things and it starts at home and whatever the schools imparts on them. There was recently a teen who snapped a picture of a white board basically shaming anyone who didn't stand for the flag in a class of mostly black kids. Ridiculous. I'm not having kids to watch them be indoctrinated like that with self hate and blind allegiance.

To answer your question on disrespectful children I will quote someone far smarter than I am. “The children now love luxury; they have bad manners, contempt for authority; they show disrespect for elders and love chatter in place of exercise. Children are now tyrants, not the servants of their households. They no longer rise when elders enter the room. They contradict their parents, chatter before company, gobble up dainties at the table, cross their legs, and tyrannize their teachers.” Shows you that some things never change. Socrates, the Greek philosopher, wrote that. He lived from 469 to 399 BC! Children are not more disrespectful, obviously.

I would blame it on the direction that our culture and society is going in. Kids aren’t taught the same respect and manners they used to be. They are exposed earlier to everything out there like the internet, which often celebrates kids with attitudes and crude behavior. Influence from parents, older siblings or older friends also could play a part in this. If you want to bring your kids up with the same respect as previous generations, I would teach them the proper way to act around adults, but when they are among children, they no longer will be sheltered. They’re going to act and speak in ways that might be shocking to you to hear it come out of your precious child’s mouth. That’s growing up.

Because kids are always have been and I suspect always will be. I am old, old as dirt . We weren’t any more respectful than the kids I meet today. Back in Elizabethan times people complained about how rude the children were. Kids have to be taught manners as well as the reason for manners and by the time they understand not just to have good manners but why they become adults. I live in an area with lots of kids, don’t know one that is any less respectful that kids were when I was growing up in the early 1950s. I will say a lot depends on what kids you interact with. A child who is not taught good manners on a consistent basis isn’t likely to exhibit them.

I would like to know that, I can’t answer the question as I’m not an adult, just a teen, but maybe seeing both sides can find out just why. The kids I do know that are rude either seem to have trouble with their parents or friendships, maybe that plays a part. Sometimes my friends and I act out if we feel threatened or offended. I personally get upset when someone calls me a child, as it makes me think that they believe I’m a 9 year old and are incapable of thinking my own opinions or don’t know enough for it to be valid. I do not respect anyone who disrespects me, so it just goes back and forth after that, for starters, someone I found here recently began mocking me for my age and said I was throwing a temper tantrum (I haven’t done that since I was 7? Maybe 8 at oldest?) I was trying to be civil, but they wouldn’t listen. We do want to be respected back, not just we respect you. Hope this helps.

It really depends on the specific child but in general, I would say children are getting smarter and because of that they have an easier time proving their parents and other adults wrong, which may give the impression of them being “rude”. The kids of today’s age are born with the internet, if they’re ever not sure about something, instead of asking an adult, they refer the internet. Upon questioning about their knowledge (which may conflict between the adult and the kid) the kid may be able to prove that the adult is incorrect or biased, giving them the impression of being rude (not to say that adults are always wrong).

I don’t have much experience, but I can just give one example, the 8th graders in my school always have to make sure the younger kids don’t talk and when I was in elementary school I was so scared of them, but nowadays they are so disrespectful, not anything like before. They roll their eyes at me, I know I sound old, but I would never ever do that when I was their age. So my opinion on this for now is yes, kids are becoming more disrespectful nowadays.

Compared to when?  Children will always act like children until adults or unless adults set boundaries.  Every generation thinks their generation was the best, most respectful, obedient generation of all times thus every generation to follow will be inadequate to the one that proceeded. Basically children are products of their environments.  If their parents expect respect, and consistently encourage their values, the child will learn respect.  Show a child respect so that you may teach respect.

The blame goes to the parents of these children, most have no father figure, and the families with both parents are absorbed with making money. Kids are taking care of themselves and parents dont have the energy or time to create good young adults. Therefore children are not learning boundaries and are left to electronic phones and tablets to raise them. Blame is on parents/ in my opinion

Because parents are abusing and neglecting their kids more than ever before. Also online communities where young people can talk honestly and anonymously about their real world situations, like quora, allows them the mental strength to not merely be propagandised into submission like previous generations. It's amazing how ruthlessly evil the average parent is. A tragedy of our decadent times. The allotment of life for our sins.

Because they aren't being taught the Golden Rules. God is out of a lot more family's and school. Because just to keepup too many family's have latchkey kids. There are way more kids who's parents are imprisoned. Because parents and schools are not allowed to use corporal punishment anymore. Mainly because we raised pampered children who are raising their kids to think they don't have to do crap or listen to anyone.

Social media, internet usage, iPhones. Most parents today do not know how to parent. They are more buddy and friend than Ma or Pa. Most younger parents do not know how to cook, clean or even work. They live with their own folks who created this age of parents who in turn created these mistakes that are disrespectful today.

in some cases? because they were created and raised by people who shouldn’t have been trusted with a hamster or a houseplant, much less a small human. in others? they’re really not, they have simply discovered how much of the social contract is coercive and exploitative, and are refusing to take part in a system that thrives on the oppression of others.
You cannot imagine what kids observe. Kids usually look at how adults behave and what we adults need to do is to give respect to the kids. Only then they will reciprocate it
Yes, because parents are becoming less attentive & disrespectful themselves.
